snippet.title: The Jewish People: A History Volume 1 Completed!
snippet.description:
Today I send the first draft of Volume 1 of my three-volume survey of Jewish History to Koren Publishers in Jerusalem for editing. Really thrilled! This work was based on research I conducted for the Jewish History Lab videos (and others), and I really benefited from the great comments from people who found the videos worthwhile. Thank you!

If you're interested in reading the draft text, please join the online Biblical Jewish History Course at www.henryabramson.com. We welcome you!

snippet.title: The Genetic History of Ashkenazi Jews (Kosher Riverboat Cruises)
snippet.description:
Some fascinating new research in this new pre-print article , soon to appear in a major scientific journal:

S. Waldman et al., Genome-wide data from medieval German Jews show that the Ashkenazi founder event pre-dated the 14th century

snippet.title: Remains of Victims of 12th c. Norwich Massacre Identfied: Ashkenazic Jews
snippet.description:
Recent DNA research confirms: the group of 17 men, women and children found at the bottom of a well were Jewish, and likely victims of a massacre that occurred on February 6, 1190.

Key article:

Brace et al., Genomes from a medieval mass burial show Ashkenazi-associated hereditary diseases pre-date the 12th century, Current Biology (2022), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2022.08.036 
https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0960982222013550-mmc3.pdf

Last full day of sailing on the Kosher Riverboat Cruise of the Seine river, July 2022. We visit the home and gardens of Claude Monet and the castle of Roche-Guyon, ending with a concert and heading back to the boat for the farewell dinner. What an amazing experience!

For more information please visit www.kosherrivercruise.com.

snippet.title: Omaha Beach and D-day (Jews of the Seine) Kosher Riverboat Cruises
snippet.description:
A brief video from the Kosher Riverboat Cruise along the Seine, visiting Omaha Beach (site of the American landing at Normandy on June 6, 1944) and the military cemetery there. 

For more information please visit https://kosherrivercruise.com

snippet.title: Jews and World War I (Seine River) Kosher Riverboat Cruises
snippet.description:
A visit to a few memorials to World War I that commemorate fallen soldiers, including Jews, along the Seine River.

For more information please visit www.kosherrivercruise.com.

snippet.title: The Jewish Street of Rouen (Seine Cruise) Kosher Riverboat Cruises
snippet.description:
Very brief look at the Jewish Street of Rouen and some iconographic elements of the local cathedral.

For more information visit www.kosherrivercruise.com.

snippet.title: Seine Day 1: Introduction (Kosher Riverboat Cruises)
snippet.description:
Brief introduction to the history we'll cover on the Kosher Riverboat Cruise on the Seine (July 2022).

For more information please visit www.kosherrivercruise.com

snippet.title: Josephus and the Battle of Jotapata (67 CE)
snippet.description:
A brief discussion of a battle crucial for the development of the first Roman-Jewish War and the beginning of Jewish historiography, as Josephus decides to become a Roman. In the video I mentioned Volume 1 of _The Jewish People: A History_ forthcoming from Koren Publishers. The draft chapters are available as part of my Biblical Jewish History course, described here:

Biblical Jewish History: From Abraham to Bar Kochba
Course information and registration here: https://henryabramson.com/course/biblical-jewish-history/

snippet.title: Napoleon and the Jews of Paris (Kosher Riverboat Cruises)
snippet.description:
Formally emancipated in 1790-91, the rights of Jews as citizens were challenged a decade later. In his typically grandiose fashion, Napoleon addressed the question by reconvening the ancient Great Sanhedrin and asked the Jews of France twelve basic questions.

A brief discussion in preparation for the upcoming Kosher Riverboat Cruise along the Seine river this July. Please visit https://kosherrivercruise.com/normandy/ for more information.

snippet.title: Read the draft chapters of my forthcoming History of the Jewish People!
snippet.description:
Hello fellow students of Jewish History!

I am in the last few months of producing the manuscript of volume one of my forthcoming book, The Jewish People: A History. I've been trying an experiment in crowdsourcing the text by allowing access to the draft text to my students, chapter by chapter, in this new online course, Biblical Jewish History. It's free for teachers and has an almost-free price for students (basically pay what you like: even a low paywall keeps out intellectual vandals). Please consider joining the class! 

Click here for more information and to register: Biblical Jewish History
https://henryabramson.com/course/biblical-jewish-history/

Are you a teacher? Free access for you! Please click here: https://henryabramson.com/request-complimentary-course-registration-form/


Other Online Courses:

A Thousand Years of Ashkenaz!

snippet.title: Jews and D-Day
snippet.description:
Did you know that Jews were among the first soldiers on the beaches at Normandy? A brief look at some of the ways in which Jews contributed to the Allied effort in World War II through the June 6, 1944 landing at Normandy. Research in preparation for the exploration of Jewish history along the Seine River as part of Kosher Riverboat Cruises.

For more information, please visit https://kosherrivercruise.com/normandy/

snippet.title: The Tenth of Tevet and Archaeomagnetism: The Fall of Jerusalem and its Planetary Implications
snippet.description:
A quick look at some fascinating new research in archaeomagnetism, the ruins of Jerusalem from Nebuchadnezzar's destruction of the city in 586 BCE, and the implications of this work for the study of Earth's climate.

For further investigation:

Amanda Borschel-Dan's article: https://www.timesofisrael.com/burnt-remains-of-586-bce-destruction-of-jerusalem-help-map-physics-holy-grail/

Professor Yuval Gadot and Yoav Vaknin explain the research: https://youtu.be/fUp7zh5MqOk

Images taken from the article are from Shai Halevi/Israel Antiquities Authority. Other images are from Wikimedia Commons.

For recommended reading, please visit: https://henryabramson.com/recommended-reading/

snippet.title: Mussar in Jewish History: Crisis and Resurgence?
snippet.description:
A look at three highly influential figures in the Jewish literary tradition of ethical works emphasizing teshuvah (repentance). Working thesis: Rabbi Moses Maimonides, Rabbi Moses Cordovero and Rabbi Moses Chaim Luzzatto were all, each in their own way, children of survivors. Their childhood experience of communal trauma influenced their world-views and contributed to their literary works.

Lecture delivered to Beth Jacob Congregation of Beverly Hills, California, on Elul 11 5781 (August 18, 2021).

Books referenced in this video:

Henry Abramson, Maimonides on Teshuvah https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B096TQ4W99/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_hsch_vapi_tpbk_p1_i2

Henry Abramson, The Kabbalah of Forgiveness
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1500635715/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_hsch_vapi_tpbk_p1_i0

Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzatto, The Complete Messilat Yesharim
https://www.amazon.com/Complete-Mesillat-Yesharim-English-Hebrew/dp/1881255425/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&qid=1629387248&refinements=p_27%3AMoshe+Hayyim+Luzzatto&s=books&sr=1-1&text=Moshe+Hayyim+Luzzatto

Rabbi Jonathan Sacks, Morality
https://www.amazon.com/Morality-Restoring-Common-Divided-Times/dp/1541675312/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=Jonathan+sacks+morality&qid=1629387267&s=books&sr=1-3

snippet.title: Is it Possible this Medieval Jewish Classic was Written by a Woman? Unlikely, but yes!
snippet.description:
Is it possible that Orhot Tsadikim (The Ways of the Righteous), a major learned work of Jewish ethics, was written by a woman? Unlikely, but yes, it's possible. Here's a brief overview of the book and the question of authorship, and a promotion for the weekly class at Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst beginning Saturday, September 4, 2021. Not a recorded or Zoom class--join us if you live nearby!

snippet.title: A Thousand Years of Ashkenaz: An Online Course in Jewish History (Introduction)
snippet.description:
A survey history of the Jewish communities of Ashkenaz, from the original settlements in western Europe through the great migration to east-central and eastern Europe. Topics to be covered include the social, economic and religious foundations of the communities, the impact of antisemitism, the rise of Hasidism and the Jewish enlightenment, modern Jewish political movements, the Holocaust, concluding with an assessment of Ashkenazi Jewry in the early 21st century.

Join the class here: https://henryabramson.com/course/a-thousand-years-of-ashkenaz/

snippet.title: Don Isaac Abravanel of Portugal (Jews of the Douro River)
snippet.description:
Don Isaac Abravanel (1437-1508) was one of the last notable figures of medieval Spanish history. He served six kings as a highly competent financier, diplomat and advisor. Political change and religious intolerance drove him into exile during his mature years, yet he wrote masterful Biblical commentary that would still be studied five hundred years later.

Part of the Jews of the Douro series, connected with Kosher Riverboat  Cruises (www.kosherrivercruises.com).

snippet.description:

snippet.title: The Jews of Egypt after the Exodus
snippet.description:
A brief overview of the history of Jewish life in Egypt. After looking briefly at the Exodus itself, we look at some major population centers in Elephantine, Alexandria, and Cairo, to the present day. 

To avoid any possible confusion: this lecture does not argue for  continuity between the Jewish population described in the account of the Exodus and the communities that appear in the historical record in the centuries before the Common Era.

Lecture delivered to Montefiore College, London, on March 15, 2021.

snippet.title: Who Illustrated the Amsterdam Haggadah of 1695? The Remarkable story of Abraham bar Ya'akov
snippet.description:
A brief look at the life and work of Abraham bar Ya'akov, a former Protestant Minister who moved to Amsterdam, converted to Judaism, and created one of the most influential Passover Haggadahs of the modern era. Some might even remember the illustrations from early Maxwell House Haggadahs! 

Join me in August 2021 for an amazing riverboat discovery of the Jewish history in the Netherlands with Kosher River Cruises (https://kosherrivercruise.com/amsterdam/)

For further reading:
Stern, David. "Mapping the Redemption: Messianic Cartography in the 1695 Amsterdam Haggadah." Studia Rosenthaliana 42/43 (2010): 43-63. Accessed January 27, 2021. http://www.jstor.org/stable/24388992.

Wischnitzer, Rahel. "Von Der Holbeinbibel Zur Amsterdamer Haggadah." Monatsschrift Für Geschichte Und Wissenschaft Des Judentums 75 (N. F. 39), no. 7/8 (1931): 269-86. Accessed January 27, 2021. http://www.jstor.org/stable/23083798.

snippet.title: 45  The Talmud  (Jewish History Lab)
snippet.description:
Very brief discussion of the Talmud. Comments turned off because, well, too many people insist on saying nasty, crazy things whenever the word "Talmud" is in the title.

Recommended readings:

First off, check out the amazing Talmud podcast on www.18Forty.org. Really interesting stuff! 
Lots of fascinating reading material available on the Talmud. A brief, very readable review of the state of the scholarship is Barry Scott Wimpfheimer, _The Talmud: A Biography_ (https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Talmud/5nxGDwAAQBAJ?hl=en)
In the video I also reference two works I wrote a few years ago, one is a short autobiographical account of how I came to study Talmud, mixed with some background on the document itself: _The Sea of Talmud: A Brief and Personal Introduction_ (https://www.google.com/books/edition/The_Sea_of_Talmud/c71GzAEACAAJ?hl=en) and another work is essentially a primer to Talmud study: _Reading the Talmud: Developing Independence in Gemara Learning_ (https://www.google.com/books/edition/Reading_the_Talmud/Ci_vKMmQgEAC?hl=en&gbpv=0_). The Daf Yomi podcast is called Jewish History in Daf Yomi, available as part of the All Daf app or at www.alldaf.org.

snippet.title: Jewish History Lab Report 1.3.2021
snippet.description:
Recently released videos:
33. The Kitos Rebellion: https://youtu.be/HdElpc9gTtY
34. The Bar Kochba Revolt (available to students now, premiering later today): https://youtu.be/UscqX3jUyLA

Researchers video: 
Review of Yigael Yadin, Bar Kokhba: https://youtu.be/imSF36pXDi8

Research Plans for this Week:
We will be stepping away from the chronological march of history to look at the them of Women in Ancient Israel, from the Biblical Period through the 2nd century.

Colleagues Live Class: Wednesday Night @ 7:30 New York Time (Register with link in separate email)

Other developments:
Thanks to so many of you who weighed in on the bizarre "merch" question: poll indicates that 41% are strongly in favor and another 45% are considering it, so I think I will go ahead with the experiment (I haven't shared this yet with  my College-age son, hope he doesn't read these notes!). Thanks to many of you who have provided helpful design ideas: I especially like the mugs (Josephus, Shabbetai Tzvi, and some guy). They will eventually populate in YouTube, but you can see them now at https://teespring.com/stores/henry-abramson

Also: thinking about making the draft text of the book version available to fellow students. Haven't figured out all the details of how to do that yet, but please keep an eye on www.henryabramson.com for updates. You can also subscribe there for email or social media stuff.

Thanks for your interest and dedication, and have an excellent week!

HMA

snippet.title: Akeida: A Conversation on The Binding of Isaac in Jewish History and Thought
snippet.description:
Genesis 22--the description of the patriarch Abraham's binding of his son Isaac and the angelic intervention that followed--is a key text in the Jewish tradition, and forms part of the Torah reading for Rosh Hashanah. Join philosopher Dr. Michael Chighel (Milton Friedman Egyetem, Budapest) and historian Dr. Henry Abramson (Touro College, New York) for a conversation on the way this moving Biblical passage has resonated throughout Jewish culture over the centuries. Moderated by Mr. David Kraus (Prague Jewish Community).

snippet.title: Black Jews: Their Place in History. A Conversation with Nissim Black and Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
A conversation with Nissim Black and Henry Abramson, moderated by Mordechai Yosef ben Avraham. The panelists and moderator will explore the idea of race and color in Jewish history and culture, and discuss the African and African-American Jewish experience over the centuries and in contemporary America, Europe and Israel. Recognizing that the world is at a potential inflection point on issues of race, the participants hope to expose the audience to the broader perspective that comes from understanding the experience of Black Jews, both in their shared historical past as part of the Jewish people and in their future history as well.

Contents:
Introduction by Mordechai ben Avraham (8m)
Historical overview by Henry Abramson (15m)
Screening of Mothaland Bounce (4m, click here for a better experience: https://youtu.be/NJzEqTD2X7Y)
Personal Experience and Thoughts by Nissim Black (20m)
Discussion and Q&A (40m)

Nissim Black has been a gangsta rapper, a gang member, and a faith seeker. But it is his current incarnation that is here to stay: an African American Hasidic Jew who brings sharp beats and hooked-filled rhymes to the masses.

Henry Abramson earned his PhD in History at the University of Toronto and held visiting and post-doctoral fellowships at Cornell, Harvard, Oxford and the Hebrew University of Toronto. The author of eight books and the Jewish History in Daf Yomi podcast on All Daf, his online lecture in Jewish History are viewed by thousands daily. He is currently working on a major multi-volume survey of Jewish History forthcoming from Koren Publishers Jerusalem.

Mordechai Yosef Ben Avraham Hazan is a Rabbinical student in Jerusalem. He grew up in Los Angeles, California, where he converted to Judaism. Before coming to Israel, Mordechai Yosef was an entertainment executive with companies such as Warner Brothers, Electus, and others. He was also was a writer for Vogue Japan, MyJewishLearning.com and most recently TheJ.Ca. Mordechai is currently co-host personality on Israel unwired hit show "Israel in black-and-white."

snippet.title: 1. Defining the Destruction (Brief lectures on the Holocaust)
snippet.description: Why do we call the destruction of European Jews "the Holocaust"? This brief lecture provides an overview of the various terms used to describe this genocide. Introduction to a series of brief lectures on the Holocaust.

snippet.title: King Joseph of Khazaria (First Person Accounts in Jewish History)
snippet.description:
Brief overview of the 10th-century correspondence between King Joseph of Khazaria and Hasdai ibn Shaprut of Muslim Spain. Widely considered a medieval forgery, the correspondence nevertheless sheds much light on how the story of the Khazar conversion to Judaism spread over the centuries.

snippet.title: Jews under Islamic and Christian Rule. I Survived Jewish History Pt. V
snippet.description:
After a brief discussion of sources for medieval Jewish history, including the Cairo Geniza, this lecture surveys the experience of Jews under Islamic and Christian rule from the seventh through the 11th centuries. Part V of the I Survived Jewish History series at the Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst. This is the advance, unedited version for members of the channel; the public version is scheduled to premiere on Sunday, March 8 at 8pm EST.

Interested in studying more deeply? Join our learning community of students, researchers and colleagues: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeNr6gwqin_7e_atjVnJcCQ/join

snippet.title: Origins of the Talmud: From Bar Kochba to the Advent of Islam (I Survived Jewish History pt. IV)
snippet.description:
A brief overview of Jewish history from the end of the Bar Kochba revolt in the 130s through the development of the diaspora community in Babylonia and the compilation of the Talmud. Part IV of the I Survived Jewish History series at Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst. 

This video is scheduled to premiere with a live chat with Dr. Abramson on Monday, March 2 at 9PM EST. The chat will be moderated to remove any intellectual vandals who might seek to disrupt the discussion. An advance viewing version of this lecture (unedited, including the cheesy jokes and tangential asides) is available to channel members here: https://youtu.be/8tTESt91GPo (for more information on membership, visit https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeNr6gwqin_7e_atjVnJcCQ/join, note that it is not available in all countries).

snippet.title: Origins of the Jewish People through the Maccabean Revolt (I Survived Jewish History, part I)
snippet.description:

Part One of the "I Survived Jewish History" series at Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst. After an introduction to the tension between the Maximalist and Minimalists schools of historiography and a look at the natural, political and economic geography of ancient Israel, the lecture moves through the first and second Temple periods to the Hellenistic era.

snippet.title: The Chanukah Rebellion: Did the Jews Really Win?
snippet.description:
A more critical look at the Maccabean Rebellion of the 2nd century BCE. After I gave this lecture I received a lot of positive feedback, but one member of the audience said I was "the Grinch who stole Chanukah," kind of an ironically Hellenistic comment. At any rate, this presentation focusses on the historical and especially military background to the rebellion under the Maccabees. 

Interested in studying more deeply? Join our learning community of students, researchers and colleagues: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeNr6gwqin_7e_atjVnJcCQ/join

snippet.title: The Jews of Lyon, France
snippet.description: Brief visit to Jewish sites in Lyon, France. Considered the "capital of the resistance" during the Nazi occupation, the local population made much use of the so-called "traboule" passageways scattered throughout the old city.

snippet.description: Brief lecture on the early days of Talmudic printing in 16th century Venice, and the contribution of Daniel Bomberg.

snippet.description: Very pleased to release the 2019 version of my study of Maimonides' Laws of Repentance, dedicated to the memory of my father. Lots more details at https://henryabramson.com/maimonides-on-teshuvah/.

snippet.description: Brief discussion of the encounter of Provencal Jewry with the writings of the great Spanish thinkers and other Arabic-language material, and its impact on European Jewish history. Part of the Jews of the Rhone series, more at henryabramson.com For more information on the Rhone River Cruise, please visit http://bit.ly/yt-rhone-cruise.

snippet.title: The  Nasi of Narbonne (Jews of the Rhone, pt. III)
snippet.description: Brief discussion of the 12th-century account of the Nasi of Narbonne, part of the Jews of the Rhone series. For more information on the Rhone River Cruise, please visit http://bit.ly/yt-rhone-cruise.

snippet.description: Herod Archelaus. Probably not the first Jew, and it wasn't called France back then, but close enough. snippet.description: Jewish History in Daf Yomi

snippet.title: Who Was Donato Manduzio? The Jews of Italy pt. XII
snippet.description: Brief overview of the remarkable mass conversion of the villagers of San Nicandro under the leadership of Donato Manduzio.

snippet.title: Who Was Primo Levi? The Jews of Italy pt. X
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Primo Levi, an Italian-Jewish chemist who recorded his experiences in Auschwitz in a remarkable series of literary works.

snippet.title: Who Was the Dark-Skinned Woman in the Sarajevo Haggadah?
snippet.description: Brief overview of the Sarajevo Haggadah and its amazing story.

snippet.title: Who was Shmuel David Luzzatto (Shadal)? Jews of Italy Pt. IX
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and works of Rabbi Shmuel David Luzzatto, important Italian Jewish thinker of the 19th century. Part of the Jews of Italy series at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: The Mystery of the Birds' Head Haggadah
snippet.description: Brief description of the mysterious Birds' Head Haggadah (Mainz, 1300). What was the strange deal with representing people with what appear to be birds' heads?

snippet.title: Who was Azariah de' Rossi? The Jews of Italy pt. VIII
snippet.description: Brief treatment of the life and work of Azariah de' Rossi, a 16th century Italian Jewish thinker.

snippet.title: Who Was Rabbi Ovadiah of Bertinoro? The Jews of Italy pt. VII
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Rabbi Ovadiah of Bertinoro (Bartenura), best known for his commentary on the Mishnah but also an important communal leader in late 15th-early 16th century Jerusalem. Part VII of the Jews of Italy series, see henryabramson.com for more.

snippet.title: The Ancona Affair of 1555-56 (Jews of Italy Pt. VI)
snippet.description: Brief treatment of the Ancona Affair of the 16th century, in which Dona Gracia Mendes Nasi attempted to create an international boycott of the port of Ancona in retaliation for the Inquisition's burning of 25 Jews at the stake there.

snippet.title: Who Was Natan of Rome? (Jews of Italy Part V)
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Natan ben Yehiel of Rome, author of the important Talmudic dictionary "the Aruch." Part V of the Jews of Italy series. For more information please visit henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: The Legend of the Four Captives (Jews of Italy Part IV)
snippet.description: Very brief reading of the Legend of the Four Captives, a story that appears in the 12th century history written by Abraham ibn Daud.

snippet.title: Who was Josephus, the Roman Jew? Jews of Italy pt. 3
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Josephus, important chronicler of the Roman-Jewish war and Jewish history to the 1st century. Part of the Jews of Italy series at henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Jewish Catacombs of Ancient Rome Jews of Italy Part 2
snippet.description: Brief introduction to the Jewish Catacombs of Ancient Rome, part 2 of the Jews of Italy series at www.henryabramson.com

snippet.title: The Origins of Italian Jewry The Jews of Italy Part 1 Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Introductory lecture in The Jews of Italy series (Spring 2019). Looks at the early settlement of Jews in the Italian peninsula up until the First Roman-Jewish War. For more information visit www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: What is the Mesilat Yesharim? 12 Lectures in Mesilat Yesharim, Lecture One

snippet.title: Who Was Bertha Pappenheim? Jews of the Danube pt. 5
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and works of Bertha Pappenheim. Although she is often recognized as "Anna O," who had a huge influence on the history of psychoanalysis, most of her life was actually dedicated to the rights and protection of women and children.

snippet.title: Who Was Max Nordau? Jews of the Danube pt. 4 Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Max Nordau, prominent thinker and Zionist activist of the turn of the 20th century. For more information visit www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Who Was the Hatam Sofer (Chasam Sofer)? Jews of the Danube pt. 3
snippet.description: Brief overview of the life and work of Rabbi Moshe Schreiber, a prominent Orthodox leader of the late 18th-early 19th century.

snippet.title: A Statement on Pittsburgh from the Flatbush Society of Fellows

snippet.title: Who Was Isaac of Vienna (Or Zaru'a)? The Jews of the Danube pt 2

snippet.title: Who Was Yitzhak Rabin? Israel: The Land and its People Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, formerly a feared adversary of the Arab states that surrounded and made war upon Israel, ultimately became the very symbol of peace in the last decade of the twentieth century. “One does not make peace with one’s friend,” he famously said, “one makes peace with one’s enemy,” an attitude that resulted in the ill-fated Oslo Accords of 1993 and, tragically, in his 1995 assassination at the hands of a Jewish extremist. Rabin’s life was inextricably bound with the relationship of Israel and its Arab neighbors.
Part XII of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College. Free and open to the community. Sponsorships are available at bit.ly/thefriendsofjewishhistory.​

snippet.title: This Shavuot at YILC! Open to the Community.
Who Was Theodor Herzl? Israel: The Land and Its People Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Once a highly assimilated Austro-Hungarian journalist, Herzl was shocked by the treatment of Alfred Dreyfus, the French army captain falsely accused of treason at the turn of the 20th century. The rest of his life became subsumed within a seemingly impossible goal: the reestablishment of a Jewish state in the Land of Israel ending nearly two thousand years of statelessness for diaspora Jewry. Like Moses, he did not merit to see the establishment of the state of Israel in 1948, but his vision and determination transformed the millennial aspirations of an exiled people into a political reality.
Part XI of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College. Free and open to the community. Sponsorships are available at bit.ly/thefriendsofjewishhistory.

snippet.title: Who Was Rabbi Moshe Cordovero? Israel: The Land and its People, Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
The sixteenth century witnessed a phenomenal, short-lived explosion of Jewish spiritual creativity, centered in the sleepy Galilean town of Safed (Tsfat). Along with greats such as Rabbi Yosef Karo, Rabbi Moshe Cordovero was one of the founders of that unusual place, attracting still more Rabbis and especially Kabbalists to the mountaintop community, including Rabbi Cordovero’s most prominent disciple, Rabbi Isaac Luria (the Arizal).
Part X of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College. Free and open to the community. Sponsorships are available at bit.ly/thefriendsofjewishhistory.

snippet.title: Who Was Nahmanides? Israel: The Land and its People
snippet.description:
A brilliant 13th-century scholar of Rabbinic thought, Nahmanides’ defense of Judaism in a forced Church-sponsored debate earned him exile from his native Spain. An elderly sage, he emigrated to the Land of Israel, where he found a tiny Jewish community, desperately hanging onto the traditions of their ancestors. Summoning upon an immense reserve of energy, Nahmanides single-handedly resurrected the community living under Islamic rule and laid the foundation for a Jewish renaissance.
Part IX of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College. Free and open to the community. Sponsorships are available at bit.ly/thefriendsofjewishhistory.

snippet.title: Who Was Rabbi Akiva? Israel: The Land and its People with Dr. Abramson
snippet.description:
Certainly one of the greatest Rabbis of the entire Talmud, Akiva son of Joseph did not begin his study of Judaism before adulthood. His trajectory of incredible spiritual growth was punctuated by moments of great personal tragedy, and his martyrdom at the hands of the Romans after the failed second-century Bar-Kochba revolt has an enduring legacy in Jewish history.
Part VII of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College. Free and open to the community. Sponsorships are available at bit.ly/thefriendsofjewishhistory.

snippet.title: Who Was King Herod? Israel: The Land and its People, Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
One of the greatest builders of ancient Israel, King Herod exploited his power as a Roman-sponsored ruler to develop the Temple, yet earned a reputation as a feared tyrant responsible for horrific massacres. HIs rule set the tone for the political climate in the Land of Israel during the tumultuous decades prior to the growth of Christianity.

Part VI of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College.

snippet.title: Who Was Gersonides? #LettersFlyingFree with Rabbi Ya'akov Trump
snippet.description: Also known as Gersonides, Rabbi Levi ben Gershon represented the early synthesis between the burgeoning scientific revolution of the renaissance and traditional Torah study. He differed sharply from predecessors like Maimonides, and his Torah commentary espouses some startling approaches to traditional theological questions. Part VI of the #LettersFlyingFree series, team-taught with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum and Rabbi Ya'akov Trump.

snippet.title: Yohanan Kohen Gadol (John Hyrcanus) Israel: The Land and its People
snippet.description:
Born in the times of the Hasmonean rebellion celebrated with the holiday of Chanukah, Yohanan Cohen Gadol was one of the most prominent Jewish leaders during the brief period of Jewish freedom in the 2nd century BCE. Caught in the swirling controversy of internal religious debate, in his old age he abandoned his Pharisaic roots orientation to join the Sadducean movement, prompting the Rabbis to issue the adage, “do not trust in yourself till the end of your life.”
Part V of the lecture series “ISRAEL: The Land and its People” offered during the Spring 2017 semester at the mighty Avenue J campus of Touro College.

snippet.title: Who Was Ibn Ezra? #LettersFlyingFree Part V with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum
snippet.description:
Destined to a life of wandering and penury, Abraham Ibn Ezra’s journeys took him across 12th-century Europe, writing poetry and composing a remarkably modern Biblical commentary. Dark and sometimes even depressed, his thought nevertheless represents a phenomenal achievement in religiosity recognized by scholars in many ways, including a crater on the moon named in his honor.
Part V of the #LettersFlyingFree series, team-taught with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum and Rabbi Yaakov Trump.

snippet.title: Who Was Onkelos? Letters Flying Free Part IV with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum
snippet.description: Translation is perhaps the most immediate form of commentary, and Onkelos’ 1st-century Aramaic rendition of the Torah was considered the greatest of all. A convert from a royal Roman family, he defied his imperial origins to join the Jewish people, to whom he gave the eternal gift of his scholarship. Part IV of the Letters Flying Free series, team-taught with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum at the Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst.

snippet.title: Who Was Saadia Gaon? #LettersFlyingFree Part III with Rabbi Yaakov Trump
snippet.description: Responding to the attraction of Islamic philosophy to Jews living in Muslim lands, Sa’adia composed a highly influential work in the 10th-century Kalam style that influenced generations of thinkers. A pugnacious and principled thinker, he engaged in several heated debates with politically powerful rivals including David ben Zakkai, who forced Sa’adia into exile. When ben Zakkai and his son predeceased Sa’adia, the Gaon took the orphaned grandson into his home and cared for him as his own child. Part III of the Letters Flying Free series, team-taught with Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum and Rabbi Yaakov Trump at the Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst.

snippet.title: Who Was Joshua? Israel: The Land and its People, Part II by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
The Bible describes how the Jewish people, emerging from Egyptian servitude and decades of wandering in the Sinai desert, followed Joshua’s military leadership to conquer the Land of Israel and establish the ancient foundations of their Torah-centered society. This lecture will survey the archeological and historical record to understand the larger context of the Biblical account. Part II of Israel: The Land and its People.

snippet.title: Who Was the Ramban? Letters Flying Free featuring Rabbi Ya'akov Trump
snippet.description: Rabbi Moshe ben Nachman, also known as Nachmanides, was a pivotal figure in Jewish thought. His sophisticated commentary on the Torah built upon the foundations laid by Maimonides and Rashi, yet in his old age he was exiled from his native Spain after embarrassing the Church in the Barcelona Disputation of 1263. Arriving in an Israel almost barren of Jews, he single-handedly revived the community with his sage vision and personal charisma. Part II of the Letters Flying Free series at Young Israel of Lawrence-Cedarhurst; team-taught with Rabbi Ya'akov Trump.

snippet.title: Rebecca Odessa's Illustrations of The Kabbalah of Forgiveness
snippet.description:
I am grateful to Rebecca Odessa, an exceptionally talented artist, who recently created thirteen startling and powerful illustrations of the Thirteen Levels of Mercy as described in Rabbi Moshe Cordovero’s Date Palm of Devorah.  I am so pleased that my translation and commentary, entitled The Kabbalah of Forgiveness, helped her clarify her vision and translate it into these thought-provoking pieces.

Rebecca recently published these works under the title “The Kabbalah of Forgiveness: An Artistic Journey.” Thank you to The Wisdom Daily for allowing them to be reproduced on my website, where they now grace each page of the Thirteen Levels, alongside the Hebrew original, my English translation and a short video describing the contents of Date Palm of Devorah. A lengthier commentary and practical applications are in The Kabbalah of Forgiveness, available in both print form and as an ebook.

Thank you Rebecca and The Wisdom Daily! Your work has added another dimension to the spiritual legacy of Rabbi Moshe Cordovero’s classic Date Palm of Devorah.

snippet.title: Who Was Moshe Hagiz? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Detractors and admirers alike called him a "zealot, the son of a zealot" a fitting title for arguably the most divisive figure in early eighteenth-century Jewish history. A native son of Jerusalem, Rabbi Moshe Chagiz (1671-1751) originally journeyed to Europe to raise funds for his beleaguered Yeshiva. Within a short period of time, however, he commanded center stage as  a major polemicist in the movement to extirpate all traces of Shabbatai Tzvi's confused legacy in the Jewish community. Chagiz published widely, both his own Rabbinic works and those of others, but he is best known for his aggressive attacks against Jewish heretics, real or perceived. Unfortunately, his zeal for ideological purity ultimately drew him to criticize the activity of a young Kabbalist named Moshe Chaim Luzzatto. R. Chagiz' persistence drove R. Luzzatto into exile and an early death.  History would nevertheless vindicate the victim of Chagiz' calumnies as one of the greatest minds of the Jewish people since the 16th century Safed circle. 

After the conversion of Shabbetai Tzvi in 1666 and his death a decade later, his eighteenth century followers may be divided into three categories. The core supporters followed Shabbetai Tzvi into Islam. Known as the Doenmeh, they continued to maintain a distinct communal status for centuries. A second group retained Jewish identity, but openly practiced antinomian Sabbatean practices such as the elimination of fast days and radical experimentation with traditional Jewish marital laws. Certainly the most visible and controversial, these Sabbateans attracted the most attention of polemicists. Rabbi Chagiz, however, was especially concerned with a third category, potentially the largest and certainly the most insidious: crypto-Sabbateans. These Jews, often very learned and occupying leadership positions in the community, secretly harbored Sabbatean inclinations and ambitions, hoping to slowly infiltrate key sectors of the Jewish population and ultimately win the community over to the messianic delusion of Shabbetai Tzvi. 

"The Destruction of Sinners" (1714) was Rabbi Chagiz' first major polemical work, attacking the crypto-Sabbatean Nechemia Chiya Chayon. The text pioneers many techniques that became standard practice for anti-Sabbatean attacks: a relentless search for hidden allusions in the writings of a given Rabbi, the meticulous examination of signatories of his letters of approbation, and the secret collection of testimonies about his personal practice. After a drama that involved several major European communities, R. Chagiz emerged victorious over Chayon. 

The experience was transformative, and R. Chagiz went on to build a virtual career as a type of Jewish Inquisitor. For some, he became a heroic defender of Torah-true Judaism, teaming with other opponents of Shabbetai Tzvi like Chacham Tsvi Ashkenazi and Yaakov Emden. For others, he was the pinnacle of intolerance and a purveyor of artificial controversy. After the success of "The Destruction of Sinners," however, there was no stopping his "pursuit of heresy" (the title of a brilliant biography of R. Chagiz by Columbia professor Elisheva Carlebach, whose career includes teaching at Touro College). When news of Rabbi Moshe Chaim Luzzatto's Kabbalistic circle reached him, R. Chagiz embarked on his final crusade. The highly respected Rabbi Isaiah Bassan, teacher to R. Luzzatto since his youth, shielded him from the most egregious charges of crypto-Sabbateanism, through R. Luzzatto was coerced into signing an oath severely limiting his public teaching. After wandering through Europe, R. Luzzatto journeyed to Israel where the ban on his activity did not apply, ultimately dying a premature death.  The victory of R. Chagiz was a tragic loss for the Jewish intellectual tradition.

snippet.title: Who Was Pinhas Hurwitz? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Two hundred years ago, Sefer Ha-Brit was a fixture in the library of every educated Jewish home. First published anonymously in 1797, this hugely popular 800-page tome appeared in forty editions, including translations into Ladino and Yiddish. It was widely read by Ashkenazim and Sefardim, western and eastern European Jews, Hasidim, Mitnagdim and Maskilim with equal enthusiasm. Indeed, the author's initial decision to hide his identity sparked rumors that the book was written by figures as diverse as the Vilna Gaon and Moses Mendelssohn. After a poorly produced pirated edition appeared in 1801, however, the author revealed his identity in an expanded second edition. His name was Pinchas Hurwitz of Vilna, and his unique passion for both Lurianic Kabbalah and modern science ultimately articulated a theological space for Jewish identity in the modern world. 

Despite its longevity through the 19th century, Sefer Ha-Brit has not retained its universal popularity over the last fifty years. This is probably because the first half of the book is dedicated to an exuberant survey of the scientific world as it existed at the end of the eighteenth century. Modern readers would find this information about subjects like the technology of hot air balloons quaint, but only specialists in the history of science would read it seriously today. For traditionalist Jews emerging into a rapidly changing industrial society, however, Sefer ha-Brit represented an accessible, authoritative, and religiously kosher view of modern science, and its endorsement by leading Rabbinic figures guaranteed its widespread adoption by intellectually curious Jewish readers. 

A recent study of Sefer Ha-Brit by distinguished University of Pennsylvania historian David Ruderman explores the larger significance of Hurwitz' work, arguing that scholars have underestimated the importance of Sefer Ha-Brit. Ostensibly, Rabbi Hurwitz was inspired by Safed thinker Rabbi Chaim Vital's Classic work of Kabbalistic ethics, Shaarei Kedushah (discussed in this column: see http://5tjt.com/the-gates-of-holiness/). At first glance, the rapid pace of scientific change represented a grave intellectual challenge to religious piety: given the demonstrable successes of the scientific worldview, what hope of survival would traditional Judaism have for the future? Borrowing from contemporary philosopher Immanuel Kant's decisive attack on accepted wisdom, Rabbi Hurwitz confidently proposed a theological posture that consisted of two distinct elements. First, the euphoria associated with scientific discovery must be tempered by the realization that later scholars will ultimately refine and even reverse these "laws of nature," just as Newtonian physics replaced Aristotelian models, and would in turn be superseded by Einstein's theories. Ultimate truth may only be found in faith, eternally outside the dimensions of empirical measurement. Second, scientific discovery should be received by Jews with open hearts and open minds, recognizing the advance of secular knowledge as the gradual unfolding of Divine wisdom, "the wonders of the Creator." This twofold proposition, a remarkable combination of contemporary science and Lurianic Kabbalah, created an intellectual space suitable for the adaptation of Jews to the modern world without sacrificing religious integrity. 

While the first half of Sefer Ha-Brit is of great value to intellectual historians, the second half remains directly relevant to a much wider audience. Rabbi Hurwitz was deeply concerned with the state of Jewish society, and the second part--significantly expanded after his work was produced in a plagiarized edition in 1801--was a large, substantive discussion of traditional Jewish ethics. Of particular value was the section entitled "Ahavat Re'im," in which Rabbi Hurwitz argued that the commandment to "love your neighbor as your self" should be understood as a broader directive to respect and hold the dignity of all human beings. Professor Ruderman points out that Rabbi Hurwitz' moral cosmopolitanism reached further than most commentators, who tended to interpret this verse more narrowly. Rabbi Hurwitz' wide experience with diverse populations, undoubtedly a result of his extensive European travels, inspired him to promote a more expansive view of human society. Ahavat Re'im was published as a stand-alone work several times after Rabbi Hurwitz passed away in 1821. 

Dr. Henry Abramson is a specialist in Jewish History and Thought, serving as Dean on the Avenue J campus of Touro College. He may be reached at abramson@touro.edu.

snippet.title: Who Was Rabbi Chaim Vital? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Rabbi Chaim Vital (1542-1620) was the principal disciple of the great Kabbalist, Rabbi Isaac Luria (the Arizal). Three days after the death of his master, Rabbi Vital received a vision in a dream that consumed his scholarly life for decades: preserving the mystical heritage of the great Safed tradition. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series, more available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who was Uriel da Costa? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Living under the Portuguese Inquisition, Uriel da Costa (1583-1640) fled with his family to Amsterdam to reclaim his Jewish heritage. Tragically, the years of attempting to reconstruct authentic Judaism under the scrutiny of a zealous Church led him, like many crypto-Jews of his generation, to basic misunderstandings about the fundamental ideas and practices of his ancestral religion.  A combination of a personal struggle with mental illness and an inability to accept the discrepancy between his imagined Judaism and the way it was actually practiced led him to become an outspoken critic of Jewish leadership as he wandered between Amsterdam, Hamburg and Utrecht. He was censured with repeated excommunication, and ultimately took his own life in 1640 after penning a brief autobiographical statement cataloguing his inner spiritual conflict. His writings are brief and confused, but they had a significant impact on the work of Baruch Spinoza, whose own conflict with traditional Judaism paralleled da Costa's in many ways. Part of the Jewish History as Biography series, more available at www.henryabramson.com.
Image: from Henryk Berlewi's book cover to a 1931 Kultur-lige biography of da Costa.

snippet.title: Who Was Dona Gracia Nasi? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson

snippet.title: Jewish History Manifesto by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: "Imagine that, while browsing in the library, you come across one book unlike the rest, which catches your eye because on its spine is written the name of your family. Intrigued, you open it and see many pages written by different hands in many languages. You start reading it, and gradually you begin to understand what it is. It i the story each generation of your ancestors has told for the sake of the next, so that everyone born into this family can learn where they came from, what happened to them, what they lived for and why. As you turn the pages, you reach the last, which carries no entry but a heading. It bears your name." Jonathan Sacks, _A Letter in the Scroll_

snippet.title: Origins of Modern Jewish Humor (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: This is a more-or-less scholarly discussion of the origins of modern Jewish history in Enlightenment Europe.  Warning: there are a few jokes in this video, but they only start around the 15 minute mark. The rest is more theoretical and historical. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series, more available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who Was Gluckel of Hameln? Jewish Biography as History by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Gluckel of Hameln, a Jewish woman who lived in late 17th-century Germany, left a remarkable memoir describing her life. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: What is Yud Shvat? This Week in Jewish History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Yud Shvat, the tenth day of the Hebrew month of Shvat, is an auspicious date for Chabad Hasidm, commemorating the passing of the 6th Rebbe in 1950 and the ascension to leadership of the 7th Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson one year later, on January 17, 1951.

snippet.title: Jewish History in the Sixteenth Century (Essential Lectures in Jewish History)
snippet.description: The Jewish people experienced dramatic changes in the sixteenth century that reverberate to this day. This lecture discusses three aspects of this century in particular: 1) the demographic upheavals associated with the expulsions from Spain and Portugal as well as the Ashkenazic migration, 2) the impact of the disruptive technology of printing, and 3) the ramifications of the Safed circle. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series, more available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who Was Rabbi Shlomo Alkabets? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Famed author of the Lecha Dodi hymn sung on the eve of the Jewish sabbath, Rabbi Alkabets was one of the founding members of the 16th-century school of Kabbalists based in Safed (Tsfat), Israel. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series, more available at www.henryabramson.com

snippet.title: Who Were the Soncinos? Jews and the Gutenberg Revolution(s)
snippet.description: Early adopters of the newest disruptive technology, the Soncino family were the first Jewish printers in 15th century Europe. This lecture discusses some aspects of the early decades of Jewish printing, and meditates on the meaning of the current digital revolution for Jewish culture and society. Part of the Jewish Biography as History Series, more at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who Was the Rashba? (Improved version) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Rabbi Shlomo ben Adret, known to his student by the acronym of his name Rashba, was one of the most brilliant Talmudists of medieval Spain. Student of Nachmanides (Ramban) and teacher to the Ritva, his writings are studied to the present day. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more available at www.henryabramson.com. This is the edited version of the Rashba lecture, cutting out some of the quiet time.

snippet.title: The Septuagint (This Week in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: The Septuagint, an ancient translation of the Torah into Koine Greek, had a tremendous impact on the later Christian understanding of Jewish theology. Part of the This Week in Jewish History, more videos available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who Was Qasmunah? Jewish Biography as History Lecture by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Preserved in a medieval anthology of women poets, Qasmunah's unique voice stands out as one of the few surviving voices of the Jewish Golden Age in Spain. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson. More available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: What is Chanukah, and How Do You Spell it? This Week in Jewish History
snippet.description: What, exactly is Chanukah (or is it Hanukah, or Hannukkah)? This short video describes the historical origins of the holiday, notes the ironic nature of its observance in the American context, and has a couple of jokes besides. Part of the This Week in Jewish History series.

snippet.title: Who Was Ibn Ezra? Jewish Biography as History
snippet.description: Hailed as one of the greatest commentators on the Torah, Abraham ibn Ezra lived a life of great scholarly accomplishment amidst great personal suffering. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Irving Berlin and Popular American Culture (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description:
At this time of year it's impossible to escape the ubiquitous holiday music that assults us whenever we turn on the radio or walk through a shopping mall. Few listeners are aware, however, that the syrupy, commercialized versions of holiday cheer have their origins in the musical genius of a Jewish immigrant from Siberia, the phenomenal Irving Berlin. Whatever we may think of the 21st century interpretations of his work, it is undeniable that Berlin had the amazing ability to express the core values of American culture in a way that transcended religious ideology.

Heres some additional notes from Dr. Carl Singer:

His actions were acknowledged with such accolades as the Army's Medal of Merit from President Truman in 1945; a Congressional Gold Medal for "God Bless America" and other patriotic songs from President Eisenhower in 1954; and the Freedom Medal from President Ford in 1977. In 2002, the U.S. Army at Fort Belvoir, Virginia, named the Army Entertainment Division (AED) World Headquarters "The Irving Berlin Center" in his honor. Also that year he was commemorated on a U.S. postage stamp.

http://www.rnh.com/bio/81/Berlin-Irving


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidential_Medal_of_Freedom_recipients   received 1977


Irving Berlin "God Bless America" - The Ed Sullivan Show   God Bless America     Irving Berlin on Ed Sullivan May 5, 1968

Irving Berlin - 'Oh, How I Hate to get up in the Morning'   Oh how I hate to get up in the morning  1943  "this is the Army"

Kate Smith, God Bless America        Kate Smith - God Bless America  introducing "a new song"

---------
I believe there was a slight error towards the end of the presentation:  "Congressional Medal of Honor" -- is likely a misnomer.  To the best of my knowledge there is no such medal.
There is the Congressional Gold Medal.   The "Medal of Honor" (no "Congressional") is the nation's highest military award.

That said -- I've really enjoyed the three presentations that I have listened to thus far:  I.B. Singer,  Shalom Alechem & Irving Berlin.

snippet.title: Who Was Aaron of Lincoln? Jewish Biography as History by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Reputed to be the wealthiest man in 11th century England--wealthier even than the King--Aaron of Lincoln was a hugely successful moneylender whose achievements included the financing of many cathedrals.  His story, while exceptional in terms of scope, is nevertheless instructive of the Jewish experience in the medieval economy as a whole. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson (more lectures available at henryabramson.com).

snippet.title: Rabbi Shimon bar Yohai Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Emerging from a cave after twelve years of isolated Torah study, Rabbi Shimon bar Yohai went on to become one of ancient Israel's most celebrated Kabbalists and a leader of the Jewish people. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org. (Note: this is a revised upload)

snippet.title: Who was Eldad ha-Dani? Jewish Biography as History by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Claiming descent from the long-lost Ten Tribes of Israel, Eldad was a ninth-century traveler with a fantastic story: beyond the "River Kush" lay an intact civilization of Jews who enjoyed political sovereignty, in preparation for their eventual return to the Land of Israel in messianic times. Surviving shipwreck, cannibals and attack from fire-worshipping pagans, Eldad's story of the mystical river Sambatyon and the Jews who lived there captivated the Jewish mind for centuries, and had a lasting impact on the development of Christian thought as well. But was he for real? Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson. More lectures available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Who Was Babatha? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Rolling her precious documents and carefully wrapping them in a leather pouch tied with twine, Babatha buried her entire legal history in the floor of the cave she shared with Bar Kochba's rebels. They would remain entombed in that desolate refuge for 1800 years until their discovery by archaeologist Yigael Yadin, and then the life of an otherwise forgotten 2nd-century woman suddenly came to light: her marriages, custody battles for her son, property disputes, and much more. The Babatha archive constitutes an amazing source of information for the history of Jewish women in ancient Israel. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson.

snippet.title: Who Was Bar Kochba? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
This is a video lecture describing the life and times of Shimon Bar Kochba, one of the greatest military leaders of ancient Israel. Famous for his stunning success against the Roman army, he was even regarded as the Messiah by many of his followers, including Rabbi Akiva.  Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson.  More videos available at www.henryabramson.com.

Join our Community! Membership categories as Student, Researcher and Colleague, explained: https://youtu.be/MQztjZZMfJg

snippet.title: The Nuremberg Laws (This Week in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: The Nuremberg Laws of 1935 defined, for the purposes of the Nazi regime, exactly who was considered a Jew. This was an essential element in the unfolding of the Holocaust, as the Nuremberg Laws allowed the Nazis to first identify, then exclude, and finally attempt to eliminate Jews from German society. Part of the "This Week in Jewish History" series by Dr. Henry Abramson. More videos available at www.henryabramson.com

snippet.title: Who Was Salome? Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Briefly but notoriously mentioned in both Josephus and the Gospels, Salome was the granddaughter of King Herod who is best known for a salacious performance that resulted in the execution of John the Baptist. Who was Salome, and does her bit part play a significant role in the representation of Jews and Judaism in medieval Christian thought? Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai (Jewish Biography as History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai (d. c. 85 ce) was one of the most influential figures in ancient Jewish history. Emerging from the ruins of the destroyed Temple, Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai led the Jewish people through the dangerous first years after the devastation of the last remnants of their state by the Romans. A disciple of Hillel, he was of the "national-realist" school that favored tactical surrender to the overwhelming power of the Roman Empire. In his most famous act, he arranged to fake his own death in order to escape his enemies among the Zealots to negotiate a peace treaty with Vespasian, who would later become Emperor. "Give me Yavneh and its scholars," asked Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai, setting in place the foundation for the existence of Judaism after the Temple could no longer serve as the center of Jewish religious life. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series available at www.jewishhistorylectures.com.

snippet.title: Medieval Antisemitism (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Concise lecture on medieval antisemitism, part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson. More videos available at www.henryabramson.com.

WARNING: this video contains disturbing imagery.

Breaking the history of antisemitism into four major periods (Ancient Xenophobia, Early Christian Anti-Judaism, Medieval Jew-hatred, and Modern Antisemitism), Dr. Abramson focuses on the third period to look at the ideological basis for the false charges of ritual murder, blood libel, and desecration of the host, ending with a discussion of the Judensau image.

Join our Community! Membership categories as Student, Researcher and Colleague, explained: https://youtu.be/MQztjZZMfJg

snippet.title: Jews in the Medieval Economy (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
An introductory lecture on the role of Jews in the medieval European economy. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series. More available at www.henryabramson.com.

Join our Community! Membership categories as Student, Researcher and Colleague, explained: https://youtu.be/MQztjZZMfJg

snippet.title: The Rishonim (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: This lecture serves as an introduction to the Rishonim, a body of Rabbinic scholars associated with the 9th through the 15th centuries of the common era. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: The Chofetz Chaim (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: Brief video highlighting the life and work of Rabbi Israel Meir Kagan (1838-1936), one of the most influential Rabbis of the 20th century. Better known as the Chofetz Chaim ("one who desires life," taken from Psalm 34).

snippet.title: The Kabbalah of Forgiveness Conclusion (Dr. Henry Abramson)
snippet.description: Summary and Conclusion of  The Kabbalah of Forgiveness: Rabbi Moshe Cordovero and the Thirteen Levels of Mercy by Dr. Henry Abramson. This is the last of fifteen short lectures on the classic 16th work of Kabbalistic Mussar known as Tomer Devorah. For texts and more information, please visit www.henryabramson.com and click "The Kabbalah of Forgiveness."

snippet.title: Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch (This Week in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch (1808-1888) articulated a strategy to allow Jews their traditional observances while participating activelly in the modern world.  Criticized from both the left and the right, his thought remains highly influential into the 21st century.  Part of the "This Week in Jewish History" series by Dr. Henry Abramson. More videos available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: The Kabbalah of Forgiveness Level One (Dr. Henry Abramson)
snippet.description: First Level of Forgiveness in The Kabbalah of Forgiveness: Rabbi Moshe Cordovero and the Thirteen Levels of Mercy by Dr. Henry Abramson. This is the second of fifteen short lectures on the classic 16th work of Kabbalistic Mussar known as Tomer Devorah. For texts and more information, please visit www.henryabramson.com and click "The Kabbalah of Forgiveness."

snippet.title: The Kabbalah of Forgiveness: Introduction Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Introduction to The Kabbalah of Forgiveness: Rabbi Moshe Cordovero and the Thirteen Levels of Mercy, by Dr. Henry Abramson. This is the first of fourteen short lectures on the classic 16th work of Kabbalistic Mussar known as Tomer Devorah. For texts and more information, please visit www.henryabramson.com and click "The Kabbalah of Forgiveness."

snippet.title: Rabbi Hayim of Volozhin (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: Founder of the famous Yeshiva of Volozhin, Rabbi Hayim ben Yitshak was one of the most influential proponents of Talmudic study in the early 19th century. The author of Nefesh HaHayim, he articulated a cogent Mitnagdic response to the Hasidic movement. More videos available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Nicholas Donin and the Disputation of 1240 (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: In 1240 Nicholas Donin, a Jewish convert to Christianity, engaged in a public debate with his former teacher, Rabbi Yechiel of Paris. Donin charged that the Talmud was a noxious document that prevented the Jews from embracing Christianity, and brought a total of 35 distinct accusations against this ancient holy text. Ultimately, 24 carriage loads of Talmuds, representing 10,000 priceless manuscripts were burned in Paris on June 6, 1242.  This video is part of "This Week in Jewish History" series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Jerusalem Day (Yom Yerushalayim) This Week in Jewish History
snippet.description: Jerusalem Day (Yom Yerushalayim) celebrates the unification of Jerusalem in the context of the Six-Day War of June 1967.  This dramatic military achievement represented a victory that was both political and symbolic, giving Jews control over the the Old City and the Temple Mount after nearly 2000 years of exile.

snippet.title: Rabbi Moshe Isserles (The Rema) This Week in Jewish History
snippet.description: Rabbi Moshe Isserles was an exceptionally important Polish Jew of the 16th century.  His commentary on the Code of Jewish Law brought Sephardic and Ashkenazic Jewry together to an unprecedented degree, and established the ascendancy of Polish Jewry over the older German community.  Part of theThis Week in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more videos available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Rabbi Joseph Baer Soloveitchik (The Rav) Jewish Biography as History
snippet.description: Known as simply "The Rav," Rabbi Dr. Yosef Baer (J.D.) Soloveitchik was arguably the most influential figure shaping the Orthodox Rabbinate in the United States in the 20th century.  From his position at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Rabbinical Seminary at Yeshiva University, he ordained some 2,000 Rabbis over four decades.  This lecture is part of the Jewish Biography as History lecture series, more available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Rabbi Kalonymus Kalmish Shapiro The Piaseczno Rebbe Esh Kodesh
snippet.description: Lecture on Rabbi Kalonymus Kalmish Shapiro (1889-1943), better known as the Piaseczno Rebbe or the Esh Kodesh.  Part of the Jewish Biography as History series by Dr. Henry Abramson (more available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org).

snippet.title: Rabbi Israel Meir Kahan, the Chofetz Chaim (Jewish Biography as History)
snippet.description: The Chofetz Chaim was one of the most influential Rabbinic thinkers of the late 19th and early 20th century. Rabbi Israel Meir Kagan is known principally for his dramatically creative analysis of the topic of forbidden speech (lashon ha-ra), and rose to prominence as a major scholar-leader of the Jewish people. Part of the Jewish Biography as History lecture series by Dr. Henry Abramson, more lectures available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: The Borders of Israel (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: This video describes the changes in the political boundaries of the State of Israel from its inception 1948 through the disengagement from Gaza in 2005. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson.  To see the Prezi associated with this video please visit http://jewishhistorylectures.org/2014/04/08/the-boundaries-of-the-state-of-israel-essential-lectures-in-jewish-history

snippet.title: Who was Henrietta Szold? Jewish Biography as History Lecture by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: American-born Henrietta Szold was an extremely influential Zionist leader and organizer, founder of the Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America. To see the Prezi associated with this lecture as well as other lectures on Jewish history, please visit http://prezi.com/nfcuussza07a/?utm_campaign=share&utm_medium=copy

snippet.title: Jacob Rodriguez Pereira, Jewish Teacher of Deaf-Mute People (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: Jacob Rodriguez Periera (1715-1780) was the inventor of dactylology, a method for teaching deaf-mutes to communicate.  A crypto-Jew from Portugal, his first student was his sister. His methodology received phenomenal acclaim, he received honors from the King of France and was named to both the Royal Society of London.  To view the Prezi used in this video and find other lectures, please click here: http://jewishhistorylectures.org/2014/04/04/jacob-rodrigues-pereira-jewish-teacher-of-deaf-mute-people-this-week-in-jewish-history/.

snippet.title: The Holocaust (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: This is a brief academic presentation of the history of the Nazi attempt to destroy the Jews of Europe during World War II. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson.  To view the Prezi used in this lecture please visit:http://jewishhistorylectures.org/2014/04/02/the-holocaust-essential-lectures-in-jewish-history-by-dr-henry-abramson/

snippet.title: Benjamin Disraeli: Jewish-Born Prime Minister of England (Jewish Biography as History)
snippet.description: Baptized at age 12 as the result of his father's dispute with a synagogue, Benjamin Disraeli (1804-1881) rose to prominence as a novelist and politician, serving several times as England's Prime Minister.  Colorful and flamboyant, Disraeli dismissed his antisemitic critics by emphasizing, rather than downplaying, his Jewish origins.

snippet.title: The Beilis Affair of 1911-1913 (This Week in Jewish History) by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: The discovery of the mutilated body of a young boy in Kiev led to the false arrest of a Jewish laborer named Mendel Beilis. Ignoring the argument of investigating officers, the Russian government under Tsar Nicholas II pressed ahead with the prosecution of Beilis, arguing that the boy was murdered as part of a Passover-related Jewish plot. After two years' imprisonment, Beilis was freed by a Ukrainian Jewry that could not be persuaded to agree with the Russian prosecutor.

snippet.title: Heinrich Heine: Poet of Judenschmerz Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Revered by many as Germany's greatest poet, Heine struggled mightily with his Jewish identity in the culturally inimical milieu of the 19th century. This phenomenon, known as Judenschmerz, was widespread among 19th century western European Jews. Despite his 1825 conversion to Christianity, Heine maintained a long, albeit conflicted, relationship to his Jewish background. Part of the Jewish Biography as History lecture series by Dr. Henry Abramson.  More lectures available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org. To view the Prezi used in this lecture, please visit http://jewishhistorylectures.org/2014/04/02/the-holocaust-essential-lectures-in-jewish-history-by-dr-henry-abramson/

snippet.title: Women in Jewish History (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: A thematic introduction to the topic of women in Jewish history, part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series by Dr. Henry Abramson.

snippet.title: "Purimfest 1946" (This Week in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: In October of 1946, ten Nazi defendants were hung on gallows erected by the International Military Tribunal. One of the most notorious, the propagandist Julius Streicher, uttered the phrase "Purimfest 1946" moments before his death, unconsciously echoing a mysterious passage in the Biblical book of Esther itself.

snippet.title: Jewish History Lectures Online by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Academic Jewish history lectures online, completely free! No hard questions, please. Three types currently available: This Week in Jewish History, each between 2 and 9 minutes in length,  Essential Lectures in Jewish History, less than thirty minutes, or the more in-depth Jewish Biography as History series, about one hour each. All lectures delivered by Dr. Henry Abramson, and available at www.henryabramson.com. Enjoy in good health! Check out our Manifesto of Jewish History as well: http://youtu.be/1yNvmk-uNZE

snippet.title: Israel Salanter: Founder of Mussar (Jewish Biography as History)
snippet.description: Rabbi Yisrael Lipkin of Salant (Israel Salanter, 1810-1883) was the founder of the modern Mussar movement that revolutionized traditional Jewish education. Controversial during his lifetime, his ideas ultimately permeated the Yeshiva system as a whole. Part of the Jewish Biography as History lecture series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Mass Jewish Politics in the Modern Era (Essential Lectures in Jewish History)
snippet.description: This lecture briefly covers the rise of mass Jewish politics at the turn of the 20th century, looking at the rise of Jewish Socialism, Zionism, and other movements. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series available at www.jewishhistorylectures.org.

snippet.title: Solomon Maimon: Jewish Philosopher and Freethinker of the 18th century
snippet.description: Blessed with a fine mind but an obstreperous personality, Salomon Maimon was one of the most erudite rebels against Judaism in the 18th century, leaving a powerful memoir that betrayed some of the stress points in traditional society. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: The Incident at Inmestar (This Week in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Murder on Purim? That's the charge of Socrates Scholasticus, whose lone account of an alleged Purim celebration that got out of hand in the year 415.  Although the validity of the accusation is highly questionable, the incident at Inmestar had a larger impact centuries later as the myth of ritual murder gained popularity in medieval Europe. Part of the This Week in Jewish History series at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: The Haskalah (Essential Lectures in Jewish History by Dr. Henry Abramson)
snippet.description: The Haskalah was a major intellectual-political movement of the 18th and 19th centuries. Seeking political emancipation and intellectual freedom, it challenged the hegemony of the traditionalist authorities, leading to widespread assimilation on one hand but exceptionally creative solutions to modernity on the other. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Rabbi Eliyahu ben Shlomo: The Vilna Gaon (Jewish Biography as History)
snippet.description:
Rabbi Eliyahu ben Shlomo, the 18th century Talmudic scholar better known as The Vilna Gaon, is revered as the father of traditional Lithuanian Judaism. Part of the Jewish Biography as History series available at www.henryabramson.com.

Join our Community! Membership categories as Student, Researcher and Colleague, explained: https://youtu.be/MQztjZZMfJg

snippet.title: Dr. Bernard Lander (1915-2010) Founder of Touro College (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: Dr. Bernard Lander (1915-2010) was one of the most influential Jewish educators of the 20th and 21st century. Scholar and social activist, he founded Touro College in 1971, which now serves almost 19,000 students world wide. This short video was prepared to commemorate the recent anniversary of his passing. Part of the This Week in Jewish History series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Rabbi Schneur Zalman of Liadi (The Alter Rebbe) of Chabad
snippet.description:
Author of the Tanya, a hugely influential 18th-century work of Jewish spirituality, Rabbi Scheur Zalman of LIadi is considered the founder of the Chabad (Lubavitch) movement. Part of the Jewish Biography as History Series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: The Eastern European Center (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: A brief overview of the settlement and activity of the Jewish people in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. Part of the Essential Lectures in Jewish History series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Bilhah Abigaill Levy Franks: The Jews of Colonial America Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Bilhah Abigaill Levy Franks lived in New York City in the early decades of the eighteenth century. Her correspondence with Naftali, her eldest son, reveals much about the inner life of a Jewish woman in colonial America.﻿ Part of the Jewish Biography as History series available at www.henryabramson.com.

snippet.title: Jewish-Christian Disputations in the Middle Ages (This Week in Jewish History)
snippet.description: Forced debates between Jews and Christians were a feature of medieval Jewish life, often with dire consequences.

snippet.title: Johann Andreas Eisenmenger and the Talmud  Lecture by Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Posing as a would-be convert to Judaism, Johann Andreas Eisenmenger studied Rabbinic literature for 19 years before publishing a massive two-volume denunciation of the Talmud called "Judaism Revealed" in 1711. His defamation of Jews and Judaism has been the foundation of much antisemitic diatribe for the last three centuries.

snippet.title: Sarah Bas Tovim Jewish Women in Prayer Dr. Henry Abramson Jewish Biography as History
snippet.description: Sarah bas Tovim was one of the most prolific authors of tekhines, prayers composed specifically for Jewish women in Eastern Europe. Her work illustrates the deeply spiritual lives of simple women, and sheds significant light on the social history of the shtetl.

snippet.title: What is Modern Jewish History? (Essential Lectures in Jewish History) Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description: Brief video on introducing the topic of Modern Jewish History by Dr. Henry Abramson, part of the Essential Lectures series.

snippet.title: Baruch Spinoza Jewish Biography as History Dr. Henry Abramson
snippet.description:
Revered by many as a pivotal figure in modern religious philosophy yet reviled by his contemporaries in the Jewish community of Amsterdam, Baruch Spinoza was placed in herem (excommunication), apparently for his public pronouncements challenging religious doctrine.
